awd_titl_txt: High Order Maximum Principle Preserving Finite Difference Schemes for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws
awd_abstract_narration:
The main focus of this proposal is to develop and to analyze a novel parametrized maximum principle preserving flux limiter technique for high order numerical schemes applied to hyperbolic conservation laws. A flux limiting technique will also be designed to obtain high order positivity preserving schemes. Numerical schemes that preserve the maximum principle and positivity are desirable because physically relevant solutions have those properties. The development is based on finite difference methods, which have the advantage of producing accurate approximations with low computational cost especially in multi-dimensional simulations. Within the proposed framework, conservative maximum principle preserving high order finite difference, finite volume and discontinuous Galerkin schemes can be designed that allow for significantly large CFL number, and therefore more efficient computational simulation. Some important applications investigated in this proposal include compressible Euler equations, magneto hydrodynamics equations and Vlasov-Maxwell equations.

The investigator is developing new computational techniques that can be applied to difficult and very important problems in science and engineering. These techniques address shortcomings in existing methods and should allow more efficient, robust, and accurate computer simulations in a number of critical applications. One such application is the supersonic flow problem, which is of great importance in designing astrophysical jets and also in the simulation of reentry vehicle for space flight modeling. Another application is the study of the magneto hydrodynamic systems, which arises in space weather modeling, in modeling electric propulsion sources, and in systems involving plasma (such as plasma-opening switches, flight control via plasma, plasma assisted combustion). These problems are strategically important for the design of the next generation devices of great industrial and commercial value.

por.por_cntn:
The main outcomes of this project can be described on the theoretical and applied aspects:

Theoretically, hyperbolic conservation laws are a set of partial differential equations used to describe some of the basic physical phenomena in the real world, especially the dynamics of fluids. The inherent complex features of fluid dynamics are mostly accounted for by various solution structures of hyperbolic equations. Computer simulation plays a major role for people to model, discover and predict the fluid dynamics, and therefore to utilize the simulation results to advance more science and engineering exploration. However, accurate and robust computer simulation for this family of problems could be very challenging. Problems arising from investigating fluid dynamics have been fascinating to scientists for several decades since computer simulation became available, however, answers are far from complete. In this project, a novel computational method for solving conservation laws is designed. Approximate solutions produced by this new method can be proven to be highly accurate, stable (The numerical solution satisfies a discrete maximum principle and total attains the total variation bounded stability).

Highly accurate simulation of real applied problems such as compressible flow simulation (astrophysical jet, combustion), Magneto-hydrodynamics, Ion-acoustic simulation has experienced a variety of difficulties mainly in the regime of extremely low density or low pressure. Failure or incorrect way of preserving these physical quantities to be positive could lead to wrong simulation results and thus disastrous scientific conclusions. This project provides a mathematically justified mechanism to ensure that the simulation is robust and the computed physical quantities are trustworthy to certain extent.

Under the training provided by the project, the PI's students made enormous progress towards preparing for their academic career. The participation of this project has inspired the graduate students’ aspiration to be successful in the scientific world. The PI's past master student Jiang Yi went on to pursue her PhD at Iowa State University. Thanks to the NSF funding, the PI's current PhD student Sulin Wang made great progress developing his numerical skill sets, nurturing his independent thinking and problems solving ability while working on the problems proposed in this project. He is committed to being an excellent researcher and educator in the future. He is certainly on the right track of making his own valuable contribution in the scientific community. 

Results from this project have been widely disseminated and made available to the public. Overall, main results are reported in fourteen publications on prestigious journals in the field of scientific computing such as SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, Journal of Computational Physics, Mathematics of Computation, Journal of Scientific Computing etc. The PI was invited to contribute a book chapter in "Handbook of Numerical Methods for Hyperbolic Problems: Part B" published by Elsevier on the numerical methods developed in this project. The PI was also invited to present the work at several SIAM meetings (SIAM annual 2016, SIAM CSE 2017 as the most recent ones) and the ICIAM 2015. The PI was also invited to present the results in several universities in the United States and China. The results have also been incorporated in the "Advanced topics in computational mathematics" class for graduate students in Michigan Tech University. 

To briefly summarize, the NSF funding provided the PI a great opportunity to explore quite a few challenging problems and successfully complete this project with satisfactory conclusions.
